title: Center of mass - comparing triangular arrangements

content.question: Six identical uniform spheres are arranged on a set of coordinate axes in two different triangular arrangements, <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, as shown. How does the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate of the center of mass of the three spheres in arrangement <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></math>, <math alttext="y sub center of mass comma A, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mrow><mi>cm</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">A</mi></mrow></msub></math> compare to the <math alttext="y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>y</mi></math>-coordinate of the center of mass of the three spheres in arrangement <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, <math alttext="y sub center of mass comma B, end sub" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>y</mi><mrow><mi>cm</mi><mo>,</mo><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></mrow></msub></math>?
